element_texts.text:
Nov. 9 Tuesday
About nine in the morning yesterday we left Jonesboro - Mrs. Buck accompanying us. Had rather a hard ride to Ben Duddings Mrs. B's uncles where we stopped overnight Isaac rode horseback we ladies in the big wagon with the driver & baggage. A two horse county wagon we had with kitchen chairs to sit in - straw over the bottom, and a white cotton cover which we dispensed with most of the way it was too pleasant to be deprived of a fair prospect. Saw a cotton field. Mrs. B. had full supply of nice sandwiches and cake wh. we ate for dinner with soda crackers and cheese, Did not stop on the way. Learned that Mr. Buck would meet us at Mr. Dudding's. Mrs. D. prepared us an excellent supper - venison warm & cold bread jelly cake nice butter & preserves - tea of superior quality etc. Mr. D. has a melodian and seems quite a musician. This morning we had fish, chicken, warm & cold bread - nice fritters and maple molasses. Took a fresh supply of bread and

meat for dinner, and Mr. M got apples to go with it.  Not so bad travelling as yesterday and not so much fatigued.  Reached DuQuoin between four and five.  Saw wise owl up on a tree.  Mr. Buck and wife stopped with us at Mr. Keyes where we are to board.  Mrs. K. seems kind, makes a perceptible effort to be very pleasant and speak softly.  This seems decidedly more like N.E.  than any place where we have been.  House pleasantly situated and well furnished - a bookcase, well stored with valuable reading, was about the first thing we saw - a treasure truly.  Our room is convenient and pleasant.  Wednesday. 10.  Mr. and Mrs. B. stayed all day.  We went walking in afternoon- in the A.M. I was unpacking trunks.  we have a good bureau all to ourselves.  No closet but nails to hang up clothes round the room.  Mr. B. and Mr. Crosby went went guning - brought home a Rabbit .  Saw deer & ducks.  Had Rab. for break

Thursday 11.  Had the rabbit for breakfast this morn. very nice - Mr. Buck & wife, nephew((unclear))started off this morning and Isaac with them to go to Mr. Roots'.  It rained powerfully almost all day - stopped about four.  Mr. Metcalf rode back after tea - I hardly expected him.  Friday 12.  finished "Wide Wide World," had first ride on Old Whity.  Did nicely but did not feel very good natured - we concluded he never carried a lady before.
Saturday - walked alone this morn. Delightful morning - begin to be some acquainted with the ((teachers?)) Miss Paine & Reynolds - very pleasant - but we think we like Miss Culver better.  The letters to day - glorious! One from mother & father - ((Jenny?)) one from Lucy - dear good ones too.  Thanksgiving is past,

Mr. Crosby out with gun this P.M. Saw quails - owl and killed a little fat rabbit.
Monday Nov 14.  Went to meeting twice today - Sermon read at 1/2 past ten and at 1/2 past ((Stime?)). At half past nine in the morning was Sabbath School.  We went and both heard classes for absent teachers.  The boy Charles who lives here days he liked Mr. Metcalf a great deal better than his teacher.  Said he explained matters to his comprehension.  We hope this will be the last Sabbath we will be without preaching.  Had a fine time this evening with the ladies and Mr. Crosby - sun till I was tired, and I imagine the listeners were too.  ((N.Fl Medicine agents?)) (in parents)
Monday 1st. ((unclear)) Isaac gone; to be away till Thursday - mayhap all the week.  I have written eight

pages home and four to George.  I washed some handkerchiefs and laces this morning - went walking all alone - read some of "Curse of Clifton" by Mrs. Southworth.  This eve. sent to singing school - very comfortably good - not extra.  (Thursday 16) Mailed letters home and to George, wrote five pages to Miss Newcomb.  Ripped my buff dress.  To line a new ((wool?)) one.  Read "Curse of Clifton" after dinner; then went out with Mrs. Keys and baby and called on Mrs. Root, an old lady who has been here thirty years - cam when there was almost nobody else - has an impediment in her speech but seems an excellent laday - think I shall like her much - two young men sons and a daughter of fourteen, who  has half a dozen or more pet cats - calls them all by name.  Went to Black ((Sap?)) Creek - rightly named - In the evening went with the ladies to reading circle at Mr. Edwin Smiths - twenty five there.  Read "Roughing it in the Bush" Some chose "Aunt Phillis' Cabin" but it was decided

against - we think we will have a private circle and red it.  It might not be so well for the younger members to hear.  
(Wednesday. 17) Read French Testament.  Took long walk alone.  Played melodian.  Went with Mrs. K. and called on Mrs. Bird and Mrs. ((Lhing?)). Sent the latter some Port Wine, because they could not get any.  Called at Mrs. ((Skimmens?)) and found a company of quilters - four or five babies among the rest.  Prayer meeting in the evening Mr. Bird remarked upon the passage - what shall I do &c. very impressive I thought.  Isaac unexpectedly came home to night.  I did not expect  him till tomorrow - saw a pretty deer very near.
(Thursday 18) Ground covered with snow this morn - soon melted a way - first moining we have seen the sun since we came - went walking alone

saw numberless blue jays and immense flocks of larks and one golden winged wood-pecker - The barren, leafless forests are full of birds.  Had long walk and enjoyed it all by myself.  Came home & commenced Hitchcocks "Religion of Geology" but stopped reading to help Isaac paint his (outline struck through) profile of the Road. painted till noon and an hour and 1/2 after.  Then went to Mrs. Campbells to sew for her.  She and her children sick - quite a roomfull of ladies and we worked fast as we could - poor woman looked miserably - ague and inflamatory rheumatism have been her troubles.
Friday - rode to the mill-two miles on "old Whity" - Isaac went about ten to Elk Pairie - gone till eve.  Mended coat.  Dr. Wall called I wrote 7 pages today. called  - Isaac finished the eighth. Went to read

"Aunt Phillis" in the evening.  Did not like it much.  Isaac starts to go - threw me over the fence and went to the door of the house -then disappears like a flash, and we saw him no more. Scamp!
Saturday, Nov. 20 - I helped Isaac make ((flags?)) this morn.  He is gone to Mr. Hawkins -will be home to night.  Read in Lamberts Physiology - and Judah's Lion cut out sack dress of the oiled print and sewed some. Talked a long while with Miss Paine about object in coming west - to teach - maps for school &c.  
Sabbath, Nov. 21.  The dear sabbatt come again - Welcome delightful morn"!  We went to Sabbath School and then heard Mr. ((Blick?)) preach very tolerably - attended prayer

meeting at three, and evening service at six - Proclamation read for Thanksgiving on the 25th.  The  ((unclear)) week Mr. Bird will preach at eleven. I believe they never observed the day here before.  We are rejoicing - it would seem as if we had no Thanksgiving if we had no sermon.  
22 Monday.  Col. Mason and Mr. Neil here . Isaac started for Mt. Y - but met contractors and returned.  Mr. Bird called - talked of ((unclear)) Co. and horse thieves - little regard for human life in S. Ill. cause of its being considered unhealthy judging from people in the "bottoms"  Isaac started just at night for Jonesboro.  I went to sing in preparation for Thursday had best singing we have had since I have been here. learned three pieces pretty thoroughly

tuesday 23 - I read and played and wrote three pages to Mother M. and read aloud to Mrs. Myers "The Rising Star of the Prairie"  Miss Paine's paper - Mrs. Keyes heard from her father of the dangerous illness of her mother and that she wished her to come to her in Chilicothe and speedily as possible.  I went to sewing straightway on a dress to Chester and Miss Weeks a niece of Rev. Mr. Wood came to sew - Her father was a ((Colporteur?)) and dies last Summer - she seems like an excellent girl.  We sewed as fast as we could.  I went to Temperance meeting in the evening sewed after I came back till after eleven.  Miss ((Weeks?)) slept with me -

told me of her father's death suddenly and away from home - probably of congestive chills - mother got to him just after he died.
Wednesday 24 - I sewed all day long - finished the little dress made apron, and sleeves for Mrs. Keyes dress.  In evening Isaac came. I was thinking of him just the moment he put his head in at the door.  Did not expect him till tomorrow.  So glad he's come to be here Thanksgiving. We all are invited to Dea. Benj. Sprague's to supper Thursday and I should not love to go without him.  Mrs. Ashley recovering, Mrs. Freeman - married! to the German Walden!! O tempora, O mores"!
Thursday No. 25 1852.  Thanksgiving.  Mrs. Keyes went as she expected.  I swept & dusted our room & parlor - at ten went to sing.  The

melodian went too, but very reluctantly.  Had a comfortable time.  Mr. Birch preached at eleven - quite a good number out, though it cloudy, damp and some of the time fine rain falling.  Mr. Birch told of the first Thanksgiving and its cause - mentioned reasons why all should be thankful, and why this community in particular should be so.  In the last twelve months $500.00 have been raised by this people for public purposes - minister, teaching, school house repairs &c.  Read after dinner.  Mr. Crosby came back from Mt. H. Between three and four we all wended our muddy way to Mr. Sprague's where we found quite a company assembled - to wit= Mr. H.,, Mrs Bird, Miss Ellen Tuttle from Vergennes, Mrs. Edwin Smith &

baby (husband at St Louis ) Dr. & Mrs. Horace Smith. Mr. and Mrs. Skinner and 3 children, Mr. & Mrs Hinckley and daughters two.
beside Misses Paine & Reynolds, Mrs. Crosby and own honorable selves.  We represented ten states of our Union - all the New Eng. except Rhode Island; New York, Ohio, North Carolina, Kentucky & Illinois.  Miss Tuttle from Vermont originally has been a year east with friends - returned last July - young lady of very good appearance - intelligent, good looking.  Mrs. Sprague has a melodian same patent of ours.  Played and sung till all the listeners were wearied out entirely & totally.  Mr. Bird & Miss Payne never tired never ready to stop, apparently.  However we did come to a finale and came home about nine. My good kind, thoughtful Isaac carried me over all the troublesome mud.

Friday 26 Nov.  I rode old Whity in the morn.  Isaac went on to Elk Prairie and I came back alone.  I put lining in pair of pants - succeeded very satisfactorily, I reckon.  Isaac back at night. Saturday 27.  All day mending vest.  Miss Paine sat with me in afterenoon.  Two letters came one from Maine mother one from cousin Lirrie Copeland. bundle of papers to from Jonesboro.  No letter from  home.  reading ((much?)) in eve.  Monday Nov. 29 - Rode two miles out with Isaac towards Mt. How.  Would have gone on with him but for Mrs. K's absence and Lirrie not very well - reached home about nine - Washed our clothes - then swept & dusted my two rooms - read some in Judah's Lion - and sewed

a dozen stitches maybe.  Read some more after Dinner and prepared a piece for the "Rising Star of the Prairie" Sewed about a dozen more stitches before tea.  Isaac came about eleven at night unexpectedly.  We were up reading "Aunt Phillis".  Several came in to hear it, and we continued it after they left.  Tuesday Nov. 30.  Isaac away to Big Muddy.  I wrote letter to cousin Lirrie and one home and at eleven went up to Miss Reynold's school - heard Col. and Em. ((Arith?)) reading and spelling - some bright little boys and girls - felt as if I almost wanted to be in the teacher's place - tis a "delightful task" Lirrie had chill - I helped her sister some about dinner - Played some and sewed a little read - went to singing school in eve. Isaac offered me $5.00 to stay at  home (but had nothing for me to do - strikethrough), so I went and helped all I could - no letters - Isaace got one at Mt. H. Monday from Elias & ((Sue?))

Wednesday Dec. 1. Winter at last but no wintry weather here - not a particle of frost in the ground.  I made my rooms neat and then went to the office with Isaac.  He gave me a lesson in engineering - quite interesting - think I shall like it, learned how to calculate excavations and embankments - expect to become quite an adept.  Came home about ten & ironed till noon - our clothes and some of Lirries - gathered a nice little boquet from the garden of white Chrysanthemums & evergreen.  The ((monthy?)) rose bush in the garden is full of dear little new sprouts.  Thursday Dec 2 Prayer meeting.  Sewed - read some Isaac gone all day - reading ((unclear)) in eve - I did not go up because I was expecting Isaac and I wanted to be down to get supper for him.  Lirry was in the circle -

He came very soon after they went up to read and just as I had supper on the table for him & Mr. Crosby Lirrie came down to get it.  I had made some hard gingerbread in the morning.  Friday Dec 3 - I called in the PM at Dr. Walls - pleasant situation.  Mrs. W. keeps no servant - Isaac gone. Mr. Holt & Mr. Crosby here in the office.  Mr. Crosby gave me some apples for wh. I was very abundantly thankful - not very good ones either.  O to peep into the barrels at home and make some slight depredations!  Isaac very busy in the evening writing to Mr. Mason arranging to go to Jonesboro in the morning and be gone over Sat.  Wish I could help him more - Mr. Keyes came fr. St. Louis -  Saturday  Dec 4 - Isaac went this morn - He does not want me to go out evenings while he is gone

I went to sing last eve - good sing but boys outside behaved badly - ran away with one of the horses and left the buggy behind - threw brickbats against the house, rung bell, and fastened us all in.  The Doc. broke open a door.  I finished my dress to day - like it much - Had good letter from mother - Jimmy sent book marks - ((Achsa?)) is married and gone/changed already - so that ((dear?)) Dunbarton will not seem as once when I go there - dear ones gone.  Sent Isaacs letter to ((RB?)) Mason, and one to mother ((unclear))6!  Seems lonely to think Isaac is gone to night - Saturday night.  We have been together every sabbath till now.  I have mended stockings this P.M. & read newspapers one saying of Washingtons

describing the watch he wished for I wish to remember.  It must be one "of which the interior construction shall be extremely well cared for, & the exterior air very simple"  A mine of wisdom is here suggested about men as well as watches-
Sabbath Dec. 5 - How lonely this day has seemed - The naughty  tears have come half a dozen times but I have enjoyed the day on the whole.  The Sabbaths here seem like Sabbaths - solemn & still - This has been a lovely day out of doors - and this twilight hour is delightful - it brings all holy thoughts to mind and makes heaven seem not afar off - Mr. Bird preached wll from Heb. 12.1.  We had a good, precious prayer meeting at three - more than have been

present before - Heaven bless my dearest this night, and aid him to do a great deal of good for the good cause of Temperance - wish my two ears could hear him speak -
Mr. Keyes goes to meeting never It troubles me - What can I do? One thing I can do, go to Him who alone changes the heart.  9 O'clock.  Excellent meeting this eve - ((Mr?)). Bird preached from "I shall be satisfied  when I awake &c - it seemed solemn. Mr. B. &c affected, three or four times, as to be unable to proceed.  I kept thinking of dear brother ((unclear))
Monday Dec. 6.  Took care of my two rooms - did my washing - helped wring the clothes and hang them out - felt some weary when through - All alone all the afternoon.  No lady in the house but my little self - Mr. K gone all day Mr. Crasby too - Lirrie went out

as soon as her work was done and Charley was off too - I really felt quite lonely - but I read "John Knox, and finished a little drawing of Passaic Falls, and played, and prepared my materials ready to commence a letter when ding, dong went the tea bell - Mr. Crosby came just as we sat down - This evening I have written four pages to Cousin Lucy & two to sister Lucy - Mary Bird came in and Miss P. & Miss R. were down. I played a number of ((unclear)) we sung rounds.  The rest seemed to feel very merry - and laughed a great deal, but I felt sad, I do not know why - I finished "John Knox" after stop singing - interesting book.
Tuesday. Dec 7 - Mailed Lucy's letter - no letters came.  I read some - worked on a book mark - cut out Lirrie's hood. Isaac came at night - brought a wire from Miss Culver and

some curious things from Ellen & Mary intended to ((unclear)) letters.  Well - from the kindness of their hearts they come - and the very best they could possibly do, doubtless.  Paid Mr. B. $3.00 for Childs Paper & Miss. ((Engr.?))
Wednesday. Dec 8.  Isaac in the office all day.  I read and sewed in the AM and made a hood for Lirrie in the P.M.  Went to prayer meeting in the evening - sick after came home  but not much.
Thursday - I walked out with Miss P & R - called on Mrs. Root.  Saw a crow - came home and cleaned two rooms - did ours twice over, for the wardrobe came and made a litter.  It is fine for our clothing - how many good things we do have - I wrote four pages to Sister Lucy - before

one for Isaac to file - He came home after dinner, and I rode "old Whity" stopped at the office as I came home and Isaac took the nag home.  I stayed at the office - wrote one more page to Lucy, because Isaac had no time.  Read Hitchcocks Geology - all the eve.
Friday Dec 10 went to walk - swept rooms helped clean kitchen then went over to the office and worked on a pen wiper for father - finished it in the AM and read all I wanted to in one No of Littells - Did not read "My Novel".
Saturday Dec 11 - got housework done and sat down to sew, but the birds sung - the bluejays & chickadeedee and when I looked out to see them it seemed too pleasant to be indoors so I called to Misses P and M - and we all went to walk - called at Dr. Halls She was baking mince pies and gave

some it taseted quite New Englandish - Went into Mr. Hinckley's new house lime so brown here it does not look white & nice in plastering more like mud - Had a fine walk - seemed like an October day in New Eng. bright & sunny - came home & worked a ((monk?)) for mother "happy new year". In P.M a letter from ((Augusten?)) read newspapers long while after mail came Isaac came about four, and I ((rode?)) till tea time.  Went to meeting in the evening - Preparatory Lecture - good Sabbath.  Dec 12. Mr. B. almost sick but preached and administered the communion.  They had comnion earthen plates & glass tumblers - Are taking a subscription now to purchase a "service".  Isaac & I added our Mite $1.20.  Sermon

read in the evening because Mr. B. was unable to preach (one of Dr. Alexander's good but nnot very suitable for here Went to prayer meeting as ((unclear))
Monday 0 cleaned rooms - washed hung out clothes and wrote a long letter to little Lucy Pond in P.M. wrote some compositions perhaps for the "Star" if it suits me, Mr. Keyes showed us painting in ancient style of his parents & grandparents the ((unclear)) probably executed by Gov. Trumbull of Conn. 
Tuesday Dec. 14 - Isaac here all day - in the house with me some sent letter home to L. Pond.  I finished composing my piece for the Star.  The ((Sisters?)). and read it to him and after dinner read a long story from (("Littell?)) aloud "Annie Orme.: then Littie and I went to call at Mr. McCoys but they were gone and we came

home again - sent Charlie for Mrs. Skinners saddle to put on Mr. Keys horse and we went riding, Liddie & I.   rode about five miles in all - farther than I ever rode at once before.  Met old Mrs. Hogg singing - no saddle.  got out of this way once.  I did not go to sing in evening - Isaac stayed at home with me- I read and worked some questions in "Embankment"! 
15 Wednesday Isaac sent away in the morning - do not know when he will be back.  I copies my composition, and went out to iron - fell in the cistern - did not feel very well all the after noon.  O how kind in Heaven to save me I though I was dying.  I think it will make me better. 
Miss Paine read the "Star" to us in the evening.  It rained hard - hope Isaac is in some good place - It seemed strange that am here - alive - once

this day I calculated the probable moments between me & Eternity! and it seems like being recalled from the dead.  What a multitude of thoughts passed through my mind that brief moment.
Thursday 16.  Slept sweetly all night Miss Paine with me and feel better this morning.  When I lay down yesterday P.M. it was worse than being up - I could not lie at all - My wrist some painful to day.  It rained hard all night - & is as warm as April this forenoon.  I worked "Love" for Lirrie and ironed the clothes and read Hitchcock  ((R. of G.?)) ((unclear))
grew cold & wet yesterday. wind blew at night very hard. I went to Mrs. Roots to reading circle.  Miss Paine sick and did not come home.  Miss Reynold not well and did not go so I went up stairs and crept into bed with her, and slept nicely.
Friday 17- "Keen blows the wind" I fear me my good Isaac "had na claes"

enough" to keep him warm on the broad prairies in such a day. "Rest ye wild storms, in the cave o' your slumbers" - Hasten home my best and truest- I would beguile thee from "weary carking cares". I would praise with thee the mercy and the love which lets me look on thy dear face again.
I lined my bonnet and now it suits me - In P.M. went to Miss Pains school -heard Evan, Smith, Philos, &c  knit & read in eve. lessons Holt, Crosby & Roots came at night. I looked quite strongly for Isaac till 11 oclock then retired, and Misses Paine and Reynold with me!  We were not in our slumberings disturbed - slept very cosily.
Saturday 18 - I took one of my rooms and made gingerbread.  had good success. Read in P.M.

dependent - cracked almonds for the ladies. made a pen wiper for George P. Alfred- In PM. had good letters from N.H. and Maine - (father, mother Jenny) (Alma Lucy & Samuel)
a "feast of fat things" Indeed, Isaac came about four.  The Saturdays return the wanderers How glad was I to see him - Mrs. Roots sent me "Home Influence" by Grace ((Squillen?)) she is a good kind woman Sabbath 19.  Methodist minister preached - "We are ambassadors for Christ" &c.  Ideas of theology not clear to himself apparently - certainly not made so to others some absolute untruths - probably did not intend what he said - ((Lined?)) out in Sabbath S. the discussion so long about changing the hour.  Appointed Isaac

superintendent - he will decline.  Prayer meeting as usual - hope I felt truly grateful - my heart full of thanksgiving for the preservation of the week past. "Bless the Lord, O my soul."  Read "Elijah the Fishbite" - Excellent.  Monday 20. Mrs. Root sent apples.  Tried to write to Lucy and Alma but could not much -troublesome wrist vetoed it all so Isaac finished my letters-  tried to sew too - but gave it up.  Read one vol. of "Home Influence" Lirrie offered to do my week's washing & ironing - I should have left it till next week.  I shall help her make her new dress.  Tuesday 21.  Mailed letter to Lucy & Alma.  Sewed for Lirr all I was able.  Read 2d vol. "Home Influence".  Considerable good to be learned therefrom.  I sewed in evening and Isaac read

loud "Hitchcock's Religion of Geology"- I do love to read with him -
22 Wednesday - sewed some on Lirries dress - went over to the office little while - Miss Reynolds examination in PM.
Thursday 23 Isaac read Hitchcock in evening - sewed for Lirrie in forenoon - afternoon went to Miss P's examination - rain, thunder & lightening all day long - common here even in 
winter - a constant blaze and rumbling a great part of the day. Invitation to Dr. Halls - Isaac said he would as soon have thought of my starting for Dunbarton while he was out as for the school house - He came after me with umbrella and big cloak and then took me in his arms beside. Read again in eve. Miss P & R down Friday 24 - mended till three oc. My dress three coats &c - gaged Lirries skirt & sewed it on & the capes too hemmed a neck fixture& wristlets Miss Paine game me-

Dec 25 Guns firing in evening in anticipation of Christmas - new idea to me - thieves about in the night - for geese, turkey & honey! another new idea. Dec 25 Saturday - sweept my rooms - wished all Merry Christmas but Lirrie - she was too quick for me - I read aloud Mr. Irving's Abbottsford "Crayon Sketches" to the ladies while they sewed.  Both making dresses.  Then vacation began yesterday and will continue through next week. "Santa Claus" brought each of them a new gingham dress - It rained some in PM but we rode over to Dr. Wells. None there but ourselves Had great dinner like unto thanksgiving.  Wild turkey & chicken pie.  Cake, apples, raisins in evening - We sung some - had quite a good visit  Hard for the horse to carry us back and forth for the mud is very deep - Letters came from Mother M. & Br. George - George almost too ministerial for his age - shall ask him to write me more little every day particulars

Dec. 26 Sabbath Mr. B. had a sermon for christmas why observed - probable it is not the right day almost certain it is not.  Nine in my class to day - all seem interested. Read Messenger after meeting - alternated prayer meeting - Wrote some to Augusta in Evening - Monday - rainy and we cannot wash - wrote to George - finished letter to Augusta and sewed a little in A.M. Worked "holy Bible" to send to Mother M. Some on cap for Miss Emerson - In eve. Isaac read Hitchcock I afterwards wrote some to Mother M - to send with Isaac's and read "Crayon Sketches." Ladies down all day, sewing and writing - 
Tuesday 28- Isaac went to Muddy River Miss Paine to Dr. Wall's - Miss Reynolds washed I would have done so too but for my wrist - wrote to Dun

barton - mailed five letters- Read Crayon Sketches - it is bright, cold day - cold for this country at least - but it is thawing now fast making nice, soft walking - this afternoon Miss Reynold's & I went to Mrs. Roots and stopped for supper - Ephraim ((makes blood?)) His mother of course feels ((alarmed?)) for him - he is not a Christian - seems thoughtful - I Iike Mrs. R. very much.  Ephraim gave me salve for my wrist - In eve. read a book Mrs. R.lent me - Strive & thrive - Mary Howett. Wednesday - Worked on watch case  29 for Isaac in AM.  He is gone to Richmond.  not be home till Friday - Miss P - stopped till about night at Dr. W. so Miss R. & I enjoyed ourselves without her.  In P.M. I read aloud to her Mr.s ((Opir's?)) "White Lies" - quite an interesting tale.  Have read quite a number of stories of late. I wonder if it is good for me?  I do not per

ceive any diminution in the interest which I take in more solid & doubtless more profitable reading - I must take care not to give to works of fiction too much of my previous time, and so waste valuable hours and lose the relish I now have for sober, substantial works.  Do you hear Nettie?  30 Thursday - Working fast on my watch case - to finish it before Isaac returns- Miss Paines maps came (Pelton's Outline ) and we all stopped work to examine the same - Fine maps they are, and Miss P. seemed very happy to see them - Mr. Wood called & invited us all to visit them this P.M. said he would call for us with the buggy just after dinner - we said yea - Too bad Isaac was not here to go and become a "wee bit"  acquainted with Mr. Wood

Mr. W. came accordingly and we went home with him.  Mr & Mrs. Bird - Mr & Mrs. G. Burbank & two children, Dr. & Mrs. Wall & Lirrie. Mrs. Peck & Mrs. Widow Wood made up the company and a very pleasant visit we had.  Such great suppers as the people here have - I do like a plain New Eng. one better - We had to night baked, stuffed chicken - chicken pie sausages - pickled beet - mashed potatoe - bread, butter, and preserves two kinds of cake, beside nut cakes - peach & pumpkin pie - We could hardly look at it all - At Mrs. Root's Tuesday eve we had nice bread, butter, cheese preserves & honey with mince pie. Enough and good enough - I rode home with Mr & Mrs. Bird -Misses P. & R. remained - It seemed lonely to come home - no body left but Mr. Keyes - with Lirrie & Charlie.  Mr. K very kidly read aloud to me

from "Lake Superior" He went to rest his weary limbs about eight and I sat there cogitating, reading & dozing till nine - then laid me down to sleep.
Friday. 31.  the last of the old year - can it be a whole twelve months since I sat in my own dear home in Dunbarton - reviewing the year just then closing and looking forward into the future to try to imagine where I would be when this time should come?  And here I am, hundreds o fmiles from that house, that treasure home - blessed & happy -O why should I be so blessed - so happy?  Heaven be praised for so great favor - Let my heart be full of thanksgiving - overflowing with praises.
Finished the watch case - Mr. Keyes reading the while from "Pelton's Key".  Untrimmed my thin bonnet & pressed it - read over Isaac's lecture - good.  Mr. Keyes & I ate breakfast, dinn

supper by ourselves.  It seemed lonely - Lirrie did sit down a few minutes though at Din. & Sup.  This evening she has gone to a "candy pull" because it is New Year's Eve - crackers firing all most all day, and will be all night.  Isaac home just at dusk - tired out and nearly sick - will not be out this eve - so the lecture rests.  Blessing on the dear ones far away to night I

Jan 1. 1853
Sat. Jan 1, 1853
Walked in morning - fair and ground frozen but so very rough it hurt my feet.  Called in Mr. smith's store, coming back looked at shawls and purchased a red and green "Bay State" for $3.00.  Came home and enclosed with it two pairs of gloves and a white silk kerchief and sent them all to Mr. Bird's by Charlie.  He brought back a note of thanks for the same- Mr. Hinckley gave Miss P & Miss R some boots.  I carried up my thin bonnet to Miss R. and $5.00 to Miss P towards the ((bags?)) I mended my delane dress before dinner - carried up bookmark to Mr. Crosby's room with "wee bit" note.  Isaac felt miserably all day - we were invited to Mr. E. Smiths but he could not go.  I went about two, and remained till dark Mr& Mrs. Shepherd & two children there - The oldest - Emma reminded me instantly of little Anna Quincy - quite a pleasant visit- big supper, as usual Isaac

Jan 2 - Sabbath & Jan. 3. Monday-
feels some better to night - I have written in Mrs. Halls album and read "Elijah the Fishbite" this eve -
Jan 2 - Sabbath -
Mr. B in A.M. long Sabbath school after sermon - got home at two - completely loaded with mud -horrible walking - Isaac not
well enough to go out - I stayed with him in A.M.  The meeting was at half past three. Mr. Shepherd preached played some - read some - Thought I should love to hear my own father speak today - give his usual New Year's record.
(Monday Jan 3) As much as two inches of "snow" this morn- began snowing about nine last eve.  I could not but clap my hands to see it coming it seemed so like home - Water froze for the first time in our room.  Did not wash because of storm & cold.  Mended coat in A.M. Isaac in office in the P.M. I went to walk - called at Mr.s Hinckley's in her pleasant new house

Tuesday Jan. 4
she wished me to come and spend a day this week.  Showed me all the rooms in the house.  I stopped at the office on way home - Mr. Holt, wife & Emma came first at dusk.  Glad enough to have them arrive - Mrs. H. takes the whole "Charge d'affaires".  Isaac read in Hitchcock - I in "Evangeline" in evening.
Tuesday. Jan. 4 Went to walk in morn - took crayons and stopped at office and drew till noon.  Had a fine time.  Messrs ((Hank & Cook?)) called at the office in P.M. finished mending coat - played & talked with Emma - Mail came for first time in two weeks - brought us four letters - me one from home & fr. Achsah - all good - I'm thankful - ((unclear)) in one letter - bit of A's wedding dress in the other - Mother says a sermon started with the letter, but when we shall see it who knows?  It may be a long time - Mr. ((R?)) got letter.  Wife well.

Wednesday Dec. 5 -& Thursday Dec.6 - 
Beautiful day - cloudless - washed more than usual because I did none last week -hug out the clothes, got plaster off my wrist doing it- worked on stitched cap & read "Buckey Abroad" Mr. Hinckley came to ask  as to visit there tomorrow with Messrs P. & R.  Had quite a long chat with him about house building and attendant difficult ((hires?)). hard to find lime & seasoned boards No lumber yard to go to - no dependence on men to do as they agree, in laboring &c &c. In P.M. Dr & Mrs. Wall called -Chapter in Hitchcock in eve.  Thursday Jan 6 -  long walk - stopped at office coming home & drew till noon - Ironed in P.M. and at three went in.  Mr. Keyes buggy to Mr. Hinckley's - Saw Mrs. Hs sister Miss Ellen Ross pleasant lady - little Abby Ross an orphan - ((unclear)) interesting girl - came home about nine-

Friday Jan. 7 Saturday 8 Jan. Isaac went to Muddy River early in the morning - I sewed and read "Buckeye" - Mrs. Peck was here to dinner - pleasant - sharp- black eyed lady -  talks fast.  Miss P&R came down to sit with me but horses came to take them to the ((Slosdon?)) Dist. to visti Mr. Givings school.  Messrs Rowly & Post came to see Isaac - concluded to go on towards Jonesboro and perchance meet him - sat with door open today - no fire.  Isaac came home about six - had not seem them - Mr. Givings came with the ladies and tarried all  night.  Maine Man. is the same Mr. Givings. Saturday Jan 8.  Warm as summer like a Mayday - Isaac at home - went to ride with me horseback - rode about seven miles very fast - some of the way - I was some wearied Do love to ride especially with Isaac All invited to Mr. Bird's in Ph

Saturday - Jan. 8
His boy Samuel came with buggy for us.  Mr. Rowley came about five & Isaac went and invited him over to tea with us - he came very agreeable man ((withall?)) a religious  man and stops on the sabbath - very pleasant visit at Mr. Bird's good deal of useful conversation - Had chicken with dressing - beans, port - bread & butter custard apple & mince pie
& cake one kind - apple sauce - for supper Miss Paine told us  how destitute they had been sometimes - last in house on table - Trusted Providence & were supplied always
Read "Independent" in Eve - Letters from Elias & Lucy -Elias at East Hampton-

Sabbath Jan 9 -1853 (& 10th
Warm - birds sweetly singing - Seemed just like Sabbath - all still and silent - ((&?)) how good on god's day to be away fromthe noise & bustle of life where it seems as though all things animate & inanimate kept the day - Mr. B. preached from "Trainup a child" &c.  Isaac took the superintendence of S.S. for the first time - succeeded well - heard his class too as usual -prayer meeting at three - after it was over we sang - Mr. Crosby, Mr. Rowley, Misses P.&R. & self with melodean.
Monday. Jan 10- Wrote to Alma Read papers - went to office and drew some - Did washing in morning & hung out clothes Read Bayard T- s letters in eve from "Tribune". (School in trouble not begin today)

Tuesday Jan 11.) Wednesday 12
Wrote home & mailed the letter and one to Alma - Sewed on cap - Isaac read some aloud - Another "Independent" for us to day - the only solitary thing for duQuoin in this day's mail.  Isaac read Hitchcock in Eve I finished the stitched cap Wednesday - cut out another cap & commenced making - Knit & read "Littell" about ((shawls?)) and criticisms on different authors Letter in "Tribune" from a California lady petitioning for a Railroad.  Mrs. Holt sat with me most of the afternoon Isaac read Littell in evening after coming from the office -Weather cloudy & rainy all the week - not cold but chilly & damp so Isaac stays home instead of venturing out towards Richmond running the risk of getting wet again

Thursday 13 Jan) Friday & Saturday
Isaac went away in morning home at night.  brought a letter from Emilie - I sewed on a cap I read "Byron" & description of Japan from Littell - read aloud  in evening to Isaac & the ladies (He had  parched corn) Friday 14 - finished at the office a little piece of crayoning - Mr. Rowly here to dinner - Read "Keeping up Appearances" by G. S. Suther and sewed in afternoon - Called just before tea time on Mrs. Shepherd - very pleasant call.  Mr. S. Was at home.  Isaac read Hitchcock in evening - Misses P&R over to Horace Smiths candy party - Saturday 14 Jan) wrote to sister Lucy and to Miss Culver - in AM. & mailed both Dull gloomy day without.  have not seen the sun since last Sabbath - Letter from cousin Lucy - kind & good.  ((Unclear)) Miss. came & ((unclear))

Sabbath Jan 14) Monday - Tuesday
Mr Shepperd preached - not very interesting.  No evening service.  We sung long time Isaac read Dr. Bacon's sermon ((loud?)) On Home Missions. 15 Monday - Washed got Isaac some dinner & he left for Richmond to be gone all the great long week good be with him.  I read Ethan Allen's captivity & finished stitched cap.  Beautiful weather in AM. but cloudy in P.M. "Who can ever dare to say - 'I will be pleasant all the day.'
Tuesday 18 Jan)Mended shirts (struck over) Went to walk - ironed- drew considerable- read "Bucky" some and in evening Littell - Misses P&R gone to Mr. Wood's - Mrssrs Holt, Crosby & Root came home about five and at office in evening - some lonely - but read fast, to forget,

Wednesday 19 Jan
Mended shirts - went to walk. then drew till noon - finished little mean picture Sewed a little and read "Buckeye" about Rome with its Vatican adorned with the wondrous art of Raphael and Mic.Angelo, its Coliseum, grand and beautiful in ruins, - and its magnificent St. Peter's with statues, obelisk and fountans.  I almost thought me there - truly I would like to be long enough to see all the glory of it and gaze on those ponderous relicts of ancient greatness - Mrs. Rowly here to supper.  Went to meeting in evening Mrs. Root & Oliver came in after the meeting to hear the melodean - I played all sorts, sad & glad, and they professed themselves highly gratified Mrs R wanted to know if it would sound so wonderful if I did not sing too - Oliver said "that just suits me" - I was happy to have him suited-

wears
Thursday 20 Jan - Friday 21-
Another beautiful day - I went walking - saw hosts of birds The larks were having a frolic on some high trees - I saw twelve singing & dancing on one - Wrote letter to Emilie before dinner & read French Testament.  Miss Reynolds feels bad about school matters - cries a good deal - makes us all feel sadly - Friday - went walking in morn beautiful, beautiful days are these I am so glad there is no rain to make Isaac sick this week- company this P.M. Mrs. Skinner & Mrs. Adams & their bairns (("wains?)) wanted to hear the Melodian - Isaac cam home before night - took me quite by surprise glad surprise.  Brought two catalogues from George - Mr. Stewart lectured on Temp. in the evening Quite an enthousiastic meeting - committee appointed to wait upon the grocery keeper & tell him his doom-

Saturday 22 Jan. Temp. meeting at nine - Committee reported the result of the interview with the groc vender - He cursed them and wished to be let alone & persists in going still onward in the old way - will be prosecuted if evidence can be obt. against him - Mr. Stewart called, stopped to dine.  Had letter from home & mailed one to Emilie - News of deaths and of marriages - This fleeting life seems all made of change - How soon all gone! O for grace not to live all in vain -
Sabbath 23 Jan-
Mr. Stewart preached - "Ho, every one that thirsteth &c very animated and used very strong language - preached an excellent sermon - Mr. Rowley here for the sabbath - Real N.H. wind to day - but not cold - Mr. Bird preached in evening.  "Strive to enter in at the strait gate:

Monday 24. Tuesday 25-
Isaac got me a nice embroidery frame to day for my ottoman- just as boisterous a wind as yesterday, - but I went to walk. Mended suspenders read some & worked a little dog - wrote home for to-morrow's mail- Heard of Mr. Clark's death - sad to think of it - where will he spend eternity?
Tuesday 25 Jan.
Fair and windy - up and had breakfast at one half past five - Read Buckey till light - then washed with Mrs H & Lirrie - After clothes were out went over to the office & commenced a picture - Mr. Cook & Dougherty called & we learned more of poor Clark - hardly enough at his grave to bring him - once wealth & enterprising and respected

Wednesday & Thursday-26-27
and then to be so forsaken in death;; so vice rewards its votaris.
I spent most of the day at the office drawing.  The mail brought letters from two mothers - dear good ones and "Ministers of Abany Cove??" long ago sent for - wrote some home in eve-
Wednesday Jan 26 - Sewed - fixing over de lane dress  Ironed in P.M.  Gentle men all gone through he day, but quite an ingathering at night - Mrssrs Holt, Crosby, Keyes Metcalf, beside a stranger from Alton - Sometimes we have a "heap" of gentlemen - sometimes none.  Went to prayer meeting in the evening.
Thursday Jan. 27 -
Sewing and reading - Isaac gone all day to Mr. Hawkins- brought some mail to night - me a letter from Elisabeth Hatch - Mrs. Shepherd & Emma called - Mr & Mrs Tuttle to dinner

Friday Jan. 28
Wrote four pages to ((Lirrie?)) Hatch - went over to the office and drew till noon  Mr. Rowly, from Jonesboro stopped to dinner.  Brought messages from Mr. Ashley and from Col Mason - The latter appoints Mr. M. Div'n Eng'r of the Sec. Div - Mr. A - requires his immediate presence at Jonesboro if possible so this afternoon he has started  May the never sleeping eye watch over him - I drew in the office alone and finished my piece Finished the "Buckeye Abroad this eve.-

Saturday Jan 29 (Sabbath 30. Jan.)
Wrote two pages to Lirrie H. and mailed the letter - went out to walk with Emma.  Mended stockings - read papers & finished "Zoological ((Temp. Com?)), called in P.M. at Dr. Wall's, Mrs. Skinner's Mr. S. Sprague's - In AM at Mr. B. Spragues - to see my little ((unclear)) ((schollar?)) H. Ross, but she was gone.  Went to Bible Class in eve- 'Tis Isaac's birth day - wonder if he thinks of it)
Sabbath. Jan 30 - glorious morning - Mr. Stewart here but too unwell to preach - Mr. B. preached well.  I read Nelson on Infidelity and some in the "Independent" and "Home Missionary" moving appeals for more laborers  O that I were worthy, and had a thousand lives to give - I must do all I can to help others to go - Not at evening meeting - did not feel very well.

Monday 31 Jan (Tuesday Feb 1.
Last day of the first month of '53 - a clean bright day - I washed and went to walk and had Nelson on Infidelity  mended a little- received a call from Martha Weeks in A.M. Hemmed a kerchief for Mr. Keyes and finished Nelson   Isaac came about half past three started at two in the morning -
Tuesday 1. Feb- Not very well yet.  Mended two overcoats & went to sleep in afternoon.  Mrs. Chandler & Sprague called-wanted to hear the melodian.  I though I could not sing a line but tried & it seemed quite easy - Mr. Bird here in eve; talked over school troubles and temperance matters - A wicked world this

Isaac gone to Richmond.  Lirrie left to day, and a new girl  (Livvie R. night?)) came - sewed some - knit- and read "Judson Offering" - what trial asuffering those devoted missionaries endured, and how glorious will be their reward.  Happy they who are permitted thus to labor - who are found worthy to suffer - Six of my Sunday scholars called
Thursday - not very well Dunham came about noon with a note from Isaac.  He wanted  ((blocks?)) at the office I went to get them.  Rainy all the P.M. Isaac came in the evening - Mrs. Holt gas some little apples now that taste good to us all - Finished "Judson Offering" Put canvass in my frame to begin Ottoman -

Friday 4 Feb. Saturday 5 Feb.
Not up till eleven! and not feeling very well now that I am up  Dear I- has done everything he could think of for my comfort.  A sympathising heart!  better than worlds of gold and silver.  I intended writing letters to day - but hardly think I shall - On the lounge from morn till night - Mr. Smith came at night.
Saturday 5.)  Better.  Mended stockings, and worked on book mark (cup and Bible).  Read paper & "Littell".  Letters from Elias & Lucy and Dr. Osgood - Tooth extractor came.  snow all the day - real N.E. Storms with wind.  Fair at night-

Sabbath 6. Feb.
Beautiful as every Sabbath has been since we com here- Isaac thinks I can not go out to ((unclear)) I am reading "George D. Boardman"- Have commenced Rev. with the notes - Mr. Stewart here and preached to day & this eve. Evening   Mr. Crosby and I alone some time - he talked freely of his love, and his longings to be a christian - I never so much felt my own inability to direct an immortal mind in the strait & narrow way!  He asked with tears - what shall I do to be saved - I was afraid to speak lest I tell him some thing I ought not - My heart went to God in prayer that I might know just what to tell him.
Wrote three pages to Lucy this eve -

Monday 7. Feb. Tuesday 8. Feb.
Isaac gone till Wednesday to Mt. Hawkins - Miss Paine at home with bad cold & hoarseness- I have taken clold in some way, and here we sit at the table and sneeze by turns.  Mailed letter to Lucy this morn. I took it to Mr. H. Have finished one for Dunbarton, to mail tomorrow  Worked cup & bible book mark - read "Tribune" - drew little picture of the "Hopice Tree" and Mrs. Judson's Grove.  Mary Bird & Phebe Tuthill spent evening I played for them.  Miss Paine & Reynolds slept with me - all our gents gone.
Tuesday. Read Tribune.  B Taylor's letters.  Built a templo. on paper.  Began a piece of crayoning fr. one of Miss Reynold's patterns.  Mrs. Holt washed, but I did not.  I wait till next week.  Mailed letter home -

Wednesday. 9. Feb.) Thursday Feb. 10 Beautiful day - I called at Mrs. Fulton's- I did want a sleigh ride -the junipers are flying about and bells merrily sounding all about us - cow bells if nothing better - Miss W. said her brother made a sleigh Monday & they rode in it at night.  Such  are the sleighs that live in this country Isaac came home about noon.  How I love to see him come.  I finished a piece of crayoning and mended a little, and then took the new "Tribune" and went to the office - read loud some - remained till supper bell.
(Thursday 10 Feb.)  Isaac at office and busy with a great many men- so that he could not even come home to dinner till three o'clock.  I read and began ottoman.  Cleaned my room very nicely & mended coat & pants.  Snow going fast - sleighing too

Friday 11 Feb.) ((Anna's?)) letter
Lovely morning - Isaac went away early.  I went down to Mr. Wood's and got "Nelson on Infidelity" - & "Dew Drops" (45 & 10 cents) shall send them to Mr. Paddocks
(Worked on Ottoman) Took me a half hour to pick cockles out of my shawl & dress - Muddy enough coming home wrote long letter to Mrs. Paddock in eve. 
Saturday - Miss Reynolds & I went to walk - began to thaw in good earnest before we reached home - mailed a letter and books to Mr. Paddock - received letter from home & from Augusta.  One from Anne yesterday - package of Temps tracts came - Mother Jenny & Father all wrote in the letter this time.  Mother's poor tired eyes write most of all - she is good - good

Sabbath - Mr. Bird unwell and we had only one service - I finished "Boardman's Life".  His was a glorious death.  There is something pleasant in the thought of dying in the midst of usefulness - something sad in the idea of living when one's days of activity are past and the "grasshopper becomes a burden."  The noble Boardman died with his full armor on - fighting manfully the battles of the Lord, with the emblems of victory - the converted haren's all around him. rejoicing in God, but sorrowing to lose the teacher they loved.  Mr. Crosby much in my thoughts to day - he seems to be greatly distressed - May Heaven grant him light & "peace like a river".  
Mr. Roots came in the eve. said he seemed to be obliged to break a piece off the Sabbath.  Will he always think thus?

Monday 14 Feb.) Tuesday. 15 Feb
Isaac gone with Mr Roots up to Mr Hawkins.  I washed.  Mrs Root & Oliver came in the evening to hear the melodian.  I played "Ossian" till tired.  -Tuesday 15 Feb - Rain, rain to day and prospect of plenty of mud over the tops of Miss Pain's rubber boots.  Lirrie come for patterns- I read Littell till noon.  Letter came from George mailed Brattleboro Vt. Whither he went to spend vacation with a schoolmate- Notes from S. Richard & J. Hinckley by Miss Paine.  I ironed in P.M. till half past three - had eight shirts this week - did not wash any last week.

Wednesday -16-Thursday 17-
Fair & bright but O the horrible mud - Miss P. could hardly get to school at all.  Stayed at noon & "Old Whity" brought her home to night.  I begin to want to see Isaac- do hope he will be home to night.- Began "Rodger Dillon" an excellent book.  this eve. a young Blanchard, just from California, came to spend the night - I saw a ((unclear)) of gold worth five dollars certainly; and a bit  of rock full of bits of the precious substance wh. he brought home with him-
-Thursday -  -(Isaac came a little after noon - brought a letter from Lucy - Mr. Smith came at night - He and Isaac intend to go to St Louis in the morning - Mr S. has a sister - a missionary in China - Mrs. Doty I think he said   I called on Lirrie - saw her child - stitches! ouch

Friday 18.) Saturday 19-
Isaac gone for a week to St Louis - Wont I be lonely!  Wrote letter to Anne Rich in A.M. Nobody here at night but women - and Mrs. H retired before eight and Misses P.& R. stayed all night at Mr. Birds so I had this whole part of the house to myself - quite too much room for so little a body - I felt alone.
Saturday - Cold morning I took a walk and enjoyed the bracing air very much  Mailed letter to Anna - Received one from our brother Ryder & wife - Just at night = our gentlemen came home, and Mr. Mitchell from Manchester N.H. with them - sorry enough Isaac is gone  Finished "Roger Miller" - commenced "Night of Toil" - read aloud to the ladies Mr. Jones and Whitlow here to dinner

My S.S. Scholar, four of them came to learn to work book marks in the afternoon.  Pleasant little company and they occupied my whole time
Sabbath. Feb. 20 Mr. Mitchell did not go to meeting - the ladies conquered the mud and got there by taking time and pains - Mr. Burbank had mercy on us, and brought us home in his buggy.
Mr. Bird at the close of his sermon gave an opportunity for any who were willing to own the Savior before men to signify the same by rising- Mr. Coasby rose - We hoped the act would relieve his mind of its burden but he seemed in as much distress as ever after meeting - We can do nothing but pray that the Spirit may guide him aright  He sat talking till 12 o'c. Saturday night= and I thought felt worse than ever when he retired-

Monday Feb. 21) Tuesday 22 Wed.
Went to walk and then washed  Gentlemen all off again except Mr. Mitchell - read worked on Ottoman.  Began blue woolen knitting at night. Wrote letter home Tuesday - No mail came.  my letters to George and home were ready - rained almost all day - Cleared away cold at night = wind blew tremendously all night = I copied a piece for the "Rising Star"-
Wednesday-23 Very windy but fair.  Think Isaac will leave St. Louis to day.  Read most of the forenoon - embroidered in P.M. Read three chapter of "Parisian scenes" & concluded I preferred America to France.  It is distressing to think of such a state of things in any part of the world - How sadly they need the simple Christian faith

Thursday 24) Walked to ((Nipigon?)) and back before 1/2 past eight.  red birds& robins sung for me all the while ((Napigon?)) walk all covered with sparkles - wild ducks were taking a morning bath in its waters, and big black stumps stood up like monuments all over it = The ice about the edges was cracking constantly,making me think somebody was there I could not see. Once it creaked just where I stood & made me start.  ((Nupigon?)) certainly looked as if somebody ought to be there to see it. It was glorious.  Mr. Holt came at night with about a half bag of mail.  Letter for me from Home & Emilie valentine fr. George Sermon & papers from Rome - No of Littell.  ((unclear)) No of "Water Cure" & Phrenological Journal - Went in eve. to Miss P.'s Exhibition

Friday 25- No Isaac last night I thought he would come- Have a real feast with my letters.  O how good they are.  It makes tears come to think I have such dear friends - I do love them  Isaac came this afternoon.  Stopped one day on the Line.  I crayoned a little piece.  Miss P. sick & no school.  I read to her from "Parisian Scenes".
Saturday 26) Finished "Parisian Scenes".  Mail brought "Young Mans Guide" & two Independents".  I rode with Isaac a short distance horseback - had not rode for so long a time it made me tired.  Called on Mrs. Shepherd Wrote little for Isaac in evening - No Bible Class because Mr. Bird sick.

Sabbath.27) Monday 28. Feb.
Mr. B. unable to preach.  Dea Sprague ((unclear)) a good sermon and ((printed?)) another service at four, but it rained & hailed and only three or four went - so it was given up - Isaac went out and picked up hailstones large as cherries - I read "Night of God"
Monday - Isaac gone again.  This is Winter's last day for this year  The frogs are singing incessantly  I have finished washing again and have written some to Lucy F.
Tuesday March 1-
Finished and mailed letter to Lucy Furber.  Singing Books came from New York.  Isaac came home in the A.M.  Box from St. Louis at night.  Sardines nuts "my Dry Goods", Books Stationary &c. therein

Wednesday Mar 2,[image] Thursday, 3 --[image]
Read Tribune & Embroidered all the A.M. Isaac gone to Mt. Hawkins-- Drew in the P.M. and commenced lamp mat for Mrs. Holt.  Little Emma sick-
Thursday, Mar. 3.[image]
Bright morning. I went to walk came home and sat down to snack nuts to be ready for Isaac.  He came about nine.  I mended his slippers and, after he came his coat-- He started away again first at noon for Jonesborg to be gone at least- till Saturday night.  Sometimes it seems hard to have him gone so much-- do hope he can be here for the Sabbath.  I am all alone-- only my books & papers this afternoon.  Been reading of the "Women's Temperance Convention"  and speeches-- and of the French Emperor's marriage on Jan 29-- to the Spanish Medalla de Montijo, now the Empress Eugenia instead of German Princess basa.

Friday Mar. 4[image] Took long walks- Drew some & read some- Finished Mrs Holt's Lamp mat and embroidered a little.  Ladies gone at night Mrses Prosby & Holt at home-- I served and read H. W. Beedhan's Lecture on the Conservative & Progressive.
Saturday March 5, [image] Snow fell in the night. The ground is covered this morn Isaac came about two o'clock brought big pieces of Maple Sugar Good!  My little Scholars came in the afternoon and worked [unclear] I got some tired-  We did not go to bed till after twelve & Isaac had writing to do.
Sabbath 6  
Snowed all the forenoon-- Went to meeting twice- not many out- only AM Elira Chandler in my class.

Monday Mar 7 [image] Tuesday 8
Washed and got tired- did not feel very well to begin with- went to office but Messrs Noel and Post- there,  and so I did not love to stay-- came home & wrote letter to Dunbarton and finished it in a hurry to let Isaac take it-- He started for Mt. Hawkins to begone all the week, so here I am alone again, but never mind Net-  Clouds have silver linings the sun always shines when he comes home-- But I do feel as if I would like to be packed away in some snuggerie out of sight-
Tuesday  Did ironing- hemmed kerchief for Mr. Brosby & rained all day-- Dr. Wall came in & sung in the evening little while -- I began " Wordsworth" in lising [unclear]- like his goodness & virtue- humanity

Wednesday Mar 9) Thursday - 10
Hemmed Mr. bird's black silk cravat - He was in and discoursed of a "Seminaire" to be instituted in du Quoin - The site is fixed - all that is wanting is means - like the man all ready to erect a mill in a fine situation who had not thought of the water power to carry it, which unluckily was minus - They would like to get $1000.00 aid from abroad.
Finished Mrs. Holt's lamp mat - and the two make a very pretty pair - Thursday ) Went to walk in the morning.  Red birds sing so sweetly One in the yard shakes from his little throat a flood of perfect melody - Sings as if her knew we loved to hear. They are darling creatures - I do hope this little firey fellow will will build his nest in our yard - Letters by Mr. Keyes - one fr.Samuel & Lucy & others business from Col. M. Everett & ((Pendergast?)) of Jonesboro

Friday March 11 [image] Saturday- 12 [image]
Wrote to cousin Lucy Brigham in the morning- A dull morning and it makes one feel dull somehow even the "Cardinal's" singing does not quite drive the gloom away-- Read & played in P.M. In evening Mr & Mrs. Roots and daughter arrived unexpectedly. probably came on acct of Emma's sickness -- Quite a long [convende?] with his honor.  Mr B.G. Roots. dissertation on  School teaching. did not suppose two teaches even more popular than my wife & I at Sparta-- related some interesting scenes in his life-"good afternoon"  teaching young ladies to sit down etc- should think if his tongue were flesh it would feel very weary sometimes--
Saturday-- Played for Mrs Roots-- Their little girl is to stay & go to school. Isaac came about nine- brought mail an letter from dear mother and M.D. Thurston  also from Eliab-- He to be married April 6. We invited!  Jenny gone to Merrimack to school- so father & mother all alone- but they have one ever present Friend Better to have such a one then hosts of Sons and daughters-- May he be always with them my dear precious father & mother

Sabbath March 13-- Mr Shepherd preached- Mr B. at ((Vergennes?))  Isaac almost sick-- My class I feel more & more interest in - They do better every Sabbath - This is one way in wh. I may hope to do some good with heavenly aid.
Monday 14- Mended & washed clothes blew all over the field. I went to office in afternoon and mended & drew with Isaac nobody else here -- copied letter for I. in eve
Tuesday 15- Walked went to office and wrote home & some to [unclear] Rider- Isaac & I together mailed the letters in Mr. Keye's absence-  I mended gloves & pockets etc.  Isaac went North after dinner.forgot his watch & brushes- I played some did ironing in P.M. in eve & commenced blue cotton stocking

(Wednesday 16.)
Mended - read to Emma ((&c?)) in A.M. Read and copied letters in P.M. Prayer meeting in eve.  I wanted to go It does seem wrong for me not to attend.  What can I do? How much I lose every week - more than usual there to night owing probably to the visiting by Mr. B- I h ope it will do much good in many ways-
Thursday March 17- Isaac came in the night - and has been home all day - I read newspapers in the A.M. and some to little Emma & sung to her - wrote some to Mr. & Mrs. Rider  In P.M. sewed, and went to office and read with Isaac- came home with Miss Reynolds - read & wrote to Jenny in evening. Wrote note in answer to Sarah Richard & Francis Hinckley - both seem thoughtful and inquiring - may the become speedily sincere christians - Sarah leaves soon-

Friday March 18.)
Isaac gone - beautiful day and I was out most of the afternoon reading in the sunshine.  Read some in Eng. History and some in "Heart of Midlothian"- Isaac home at night also Mr. Keyes, Holt Roots, and Mr. ((Riving?)) to spend the night - Finished letters to Jenny & to Mr. & Mrs. ((Rider?)) to mail tomorrow-
Saturday 19.)
Rode horseback with Isaac - went to office & read till dinner.  P.M. embroidered and read - Mr. Rowley came - wrote some to Mr. & Mrs. Rider.  Expected Mrs. Keyes but disappointed - long talk with Mrs. Holt.
Sabbath 20)
Mr. Bird preached twice - rained in Afternoon - I read stories of the Shorter Chatecism - very interesting, and apt in their application - by

Monday 21 March) Tuesday & We3dnesday
Read - mailed letters & in A.M. and wrote letter to mother M.  Isaac to Mr. Hawkins in P.M. Mrs. Holt sat with me in Afternoon-
Tuesday 22- Mailed more letters - mail brought Littell, Home Missionary & Phrenological Journal - Washed in the morning.  Worked sweet home for Mr.s Holt - she went to Mrs. Wall's for me.  Sarah Richart called the moment I spoke of her feelings she burst into tears and wept a long time - said she tried to be a christian and sometimes hoped she was but feared she deceived herself - Gave her bible & tracts.  May the Savior take car of her, and make her his own - Alone most of eve. copying letters
Wednesday 23.)
Lovely morning - birds singing & prairie fowls bellowing - chanticleer crowing & flapping his wings in the Barnyard. Isaac home in P.M. Mr. Keyes just at suppertime and Mrs. Keyes before

we were through, with Chester - both look well and glad to get home as we are to have them.
Thursday 24) Put pocket in a coat then went over to the office to read and draw till dinner - Went to Miss Paine's Examination in P.M. very good, but the hard benches tire me woefully - Exhibition this eve, but I stay at home - Isaac is here too- I have written some home.  We had letters from Mother M, Anna, Lucy & Elias- 
Friday 25) Wrote three pages to Anne.  Sewed some.  Miss R's examination in P.M. Barrel of apples just at night from St. Louis - We looked all over & wiped them- Went out to see magnificent prairie fires - so near we saw the blaze streaming up - trembling & flickering.& spreading.  It seemed dangerous on such a boisterous eve - but the scene was the more splendid- I. read to me.

Saturday 26)  Sewed
Sewed and read and walked some with M.E.Roots. attended to her work.  Letter from dear home - new of March Meeting- Cousin Sewals beautiful wife dead- O that he had a heavenly Friend to love & trust in!
Sabbath 27 March
Mr. Bird preached twice and after sec. service was a church meeting to decide whether or not to Install Mr. Bird as regular Pastor of this chh.  Decided in the affirmative.  This is well for the people, & for Mr. B.
Monday 28 March-
I do not wash to day - Lirrie had Mrs. Keyes washing to do and I thought there would be no room for me, and did not feelmuch like it either.  A day without a cloud this is-

Tuesday 29-
I have been at office about all day - writing &c-wrote to Lucy & Albina- Isaac wrote to the mother & Charles and Samuel - Tuesday - wrote note to Mother  M. went riding with Isaac off on the Line three miles & back -Papers came from home S.S. ((corn?)) Report &c. Putnam's Monthly for March. -Back troubled me to day some-
Wednesday, 30 March - Isaac went to Big Muddy - home at night. My back some sick & sore. Read to Miss Nichols & Paine while they sewed on riding dresses - Miss R's ash colored cambric - P's black & blue linen gingham - Made skirt & little sack separate. Mr.. Holt came home and said they would go to their house to-morrow- so we then lose four of our company-

Thursday 31 March-
Sewed some - read the "Monthly" snoosed good long while after Dinner - Went to the office little while - mended ((unclear)) dress - Mr. H. & wife & Emma & Philander gone.
Friday april 1.
Isaac went to Big Muddy this morn expecting to be home to night - but instead Mr Crosby came with a letter from him telling me Mr. ((Mason?)) had sent for him to Jonesboro', and he must go - Not be back till next week.  No coat but his shabbiest - no change of any kind - not even a brush for his hair I reckon, or "Siller" to pay h is bills  - Well, he is worthy to be trusted. - Good be with him - good, better, very best.

Saturday April 2
I found rotten apples & carried a dish of them out to Mrs. Keyes - Mr. Crosby & ladies ate some in the parlor. I told Mr. bird to send boy for some but he has not appeared as yet.  They'll "na" be like the widows oil & meal I'm thinking.  They'll na stop wi' us lang.  Amaist ilka one is sick now.  I wrote ever so much for Mr Keyes making returns to the P.O Department.  read some in "Tell Tale" & "Littell".  New No of the latter came, Independent, Water ((unclear)) and letters from Cousin Lucy B. at St. Charles.  Items of news from Westboro &c . Mr. Holt here at night Crosby & ((Euen?)) Gave  Mr. H & Isaac's note to him  finished all but few last pages in the "Tell Tale" in evening

Sabbath Apr. 3)
No dear good Isaac to read with me to day - All alone he is at Jonesboro.  Clothes hardly proper for chh. wonder if he to go. Mr. Holt here but not go to meeting Stayed at the office - I read Independent & Young Man's Guide  Mr. Bird & wife sailed March 14 for Lyria - a blessing go with them.  Read statements of G. Spring D.D. that it would seem impossible for a good man in his right mind to make - regarding Slavery & the Fugitive Slave Law.  What can posses him? ((He?)) can not be the good One. 
Read about houses being forbidden to the Jews because they procured them from Egypt, and idolatrous nation, which might enslave them -

Monday Apr. 4) Washed and wrote to Augusta - Sewed some lay down & slept some time in P.M.
Tuesday 5-
Mailed letters.  Looked over apples and cut them ready to eat.  Went riding with Miss Reynolds.  Called on Mrs. Lawrence- Seven little children she has - means to send them to S.S. as soon as she can - called as Mr. Burbanks - pleasant people from Haverhill N.H. Isaac came unexpectedly in P.M. Mr & Mrs. Ashley in great affliction - three children probably dead before now - can think of nothing else a desolate house it must be.  Mr. & Mrs. Buck came at night on way to Jonesboro'.  Will stop till Thursday morn. here.

Wednesday Apr. 6) The wedding day - sunny & bright- So be their lives.
Entertained Mrs. B. as well as I was able read, served & talked Isaac very busy at office - Contractor there, Mr. Roots & c.
Thursday 7-)
Real motherly letter from home - dear N.H. home - enclosing one from Jenny to Father & mother.  also letter from cousin L. Pond - & one from Montague.  Was at the office little while both forenoon & after noon -
Friday - 8. Over at the office about all day - sewing, read Putnam's monthly ((unclear))
Saturday - 9. Letter from George- served in A.M. Trimmed Lirries Bonnet in P.M.  ME Roots here all day - Had considerable to do to take care of her and amuse her

Sabbath.10-) Lovely Sabbath singing birds. springing grass and sweet flowers are all around us - All doing their part to make the word beautiful and the people in it happy, pure & good.  How many precious lessons they teach - Every little flower speaks
Monday 11-Washed - read some. Wrote to George, for Isaac to take to Mt. Hawkins - He left about noon - Cut out ((hum?)) sack and sewed some-
Tuesday, 12. Mrs. Weeks here - I ironed and wrote letter home.  Sent for edging in it.  Went over to the office and into Mr. Smith's store -

Wednesday 13 
Sewed finished sack Mr. Rowley called.  I called at Mr. Bird's left "New ((Englanders"?))  He and Mary go to Presbytery Monday. at Brightons - Mr. & Mrs Buck came about three o'clock.  Isaac came unexpectedly in the evening brought flowers - so pretty laid away in his book I did not love to disturb them even for the sake of preserving-

Thursday 14-
Analysed some flowers in the morning and put some pressing - Isaac went about eleven to Big.Muddy-Mr. & Mrs. Buck started in morning for home.  Mr. Keys came with letter from Lucy & mother M.   Isaac brought beautiful flowers of the Red bud.  Heard in evening of Jane Skipworth drowned in Big Muddy. fording the stream in too deep a place all alone.  Where is she now? It seems a sad way to meet death. Why seems it so:  should not a Christian welcome death come when & where and how it may?  If it be so sweet to live on God's footstool what must it be to dwell near his throne

Friday 15-
Isaac went to Big Muddy - home at night
Saturday 16-
Went to meeting at eleven Mr. Wood preached - very good Mr Steward in evening - I did not go- Isaac home.  Mr. Mitchel here.
Sabbath. 17- Mr. Stewart here and preached - in A.M. and evening - communion at half past two.  Two children baptised.  house very full & meetings quite interesting

Monday.18.
Isaac home in A.M. Put Dick in buggy to try  him thinking to go to Mt Hawkins but he was horribly frightened by the buffalo.  too bad for now we must relinquish the ride.  Mrs Keyes did my washing to day.  Isaac & I went into the woods horseback. by Black Sop. found some new flowers. Had fine ride six men here to dinner- big   Mr. Smith Mr -   Mr. Rowley- Crosby & Mitchell.  All went away before night and Isaac with the rest.  I wrote letter home in evening to mother

Tuesday 19-
Wrote to Lucy Furber long letter.  Put up the mail
Wednesday - 20.  Sewed some- mending.  Mr. Burgess & wife came over to take charge of boarding - Mrs. Sprague called in P.M. I went out with her to make calls.  Went to Mrs Shopmans.  She is sick - had two night cap & hood on in bed - warm day - called at Mr. ((T. Thimys?)) and at Mr. H. Smith's.  Four  
Isaac had come home when I came back - brought a book full of flowers - I went over to the office  Mr. Roots there.  He came over to supper.  Studied flowers in evening some.

Thursday.21.1
Isaac at office in A.M.  I was with him - went away to Big Muddy in P.M.  I went over to Mrs Keyes new room at Mr Burgess's  Very pleasant room.  cool and large enough Read "Lady at Home" by T.S. Arthur.  Mended stocking
Friday 22.
Lovely morning - thrush singing finely in the yard.  The air seems nectar  Isaac home by noon.
Saturday.23- Isaac home all day - Tried to put Old White in buggy - but he chose not to be put in.  Messrs Mitchel & Crosby Rowledy & Willis came to spend sabbath.

Sabbath 24
Mr B. gone & no preaching - sermon read at 10 1/2 o'clock and four in the p.M. Some increase in S.S. Letter from home & Quincy yesterday.
Monday 25-((1?))
Books came from G.P. Putnam N. York.  Some wrong & so makes trouble for Isaac - He leaves for Vandalia, to be away for the week, this afternoon
Tuesday 26 Isaac came home last night and Col. Mason & Mr Roots with him - will not go to Vandalia now - To day they are off on the line - Big Muddy &c.  I wrote to Emilie-
27 Wednesday - delightful morn.  Isaac home just after breakfast - Mr. ((Smith?)) here to dinner - Mr. Post for the night. Isaac gone to Mr. Hawkins & Little Muddy

Thursday 28. P
Read "Ivanhoe" and some of "Rural Towns" - sewed some- and had a snooze after dinner, -then helped sow flower seeds with Mrs. Keyes.  Long talk with her in evening.
29-Friday- some rainy - some not rainy - sewed almost all day - Hoped Isaac will come, but I do not believe he will till tomorrow.  Mrs. Keyes here all the evening.
Saturday ((So?)) - last day of Avril so go the months.  No Isaac yesterday but he came before dinner to day - came with Mr. Root's buggy  Brought a letter from Charles and Albina and Lucy T -& Charles (struck through) Samuel.  I went to ride in P.M. little while - Four Sabbath scholars here to work marks - I love them all -

Sabbath May 1.-
Mr. Bird preached - I only went in the morning - He is to be installed in Sept.
Number of showers to day with bright sunshine between, and even while the drops came too som of the time.  Isaac read to me in afternoon. "Sunday in the 19th century".  Wrote some to both mothers -
Monday.  Isaac home to day - he rode away before dinner to see a quarry.  Mr. Post called to see him, and I told him well as I could where he was, but Isaac returned with out having seen him.  Watched the little Humming birds about the honeysuckle.  Had Lettuce & Pepper grass for dinner-Asparagus - I went to the office after dinner (written above line) scholars brought many flowers

Tuesday - May 3
I mailed letters home & to Bangor + mother M. Received one from home.  I went to ride in the buggy with Isaac out to our land on the line- Prairie covered with flowers. Phloix. Puccoon.  sorrel flower - a few lingering spring beauties, Ranunculus.  Wild Indigo &c. Several fine showers in the P.M. Two or three drops fell on my face just as we rode into the yard and a shower in five minutes more.  Fortunate we! Isaac put me on the bed soon after dinner and went away to the office.  I sewed and read a little and then sleep shut my eyelids fast and then I slumbered till a few minutes before the first supp. bell!  I was provoked, for I meant to accomplish considerable to day

Thursday Wednesday, May 4
Isaac busy in office all day.  Mr. buck here - Mr. Smith too.  Mr Roots to dinner.  I ripped my striped gingham sponged & ironed it and cut over the waist - Read Ivanhoe little.  Sweet scented honeysuckle in full glory to day - perfect mass of flowers, filling the air with delicious perfume - Some in the vase on the table scents the whole room-
Thinking of Mr Crosby tonight  Had some fears the last time he was here that his serious feelings were forsaking him.  Have prayers ((unclear)) for him as they should have done?  I fear not - He has a soul to save - may it not be lost through the neglect of Christ's professed disciples

Thursday May 5 -
Lovely day - I walked in the garden early in the morning.  Currants almost large enough to use.  Apples, peaches, plum &c getting to be quite important, observable characters.  Tree hang full - May no untimely frost destroy them.  Mr buck & Isaac busy in the office.  I. brought up the Depot plans - very nicely drawn.  I napped after dinner little while  Sewed some - Went out in the "lot" to walk, - found growing there about every variety of wild flower that abound in the region. gather from nature's own garden a fine showy boquet of Hyacinth Indigo, Larkspur - Painted cup  Red clover - Five finger - Blue eyed grass, Betony Phlox - Ranunculus - All these in the lot about the house - Others are out of bloom and others still to come in their season "Sweet wildwood flowers"
Marginal writing:  Sarah & Harriet brought me more flowers at recess. } Finished making over my dress to day - Ironed in the P.M. All alone in evening

Friday May 6 - I
Isaac went to Big Muddy in morning.  I rumaged drawers and tried to make them more orderly - A company of travellers came to dinner.  Murphysboro people been to Benton to Court as witnesses, lawyers, Sherrifs &c. After dinner Mrs. Keyes "bhetty" and I went to make calls. Mrs Adams, Also Mrs ((Thing?)), Mr. Campbells- Mrs. D. ((Thing?)) said she was born & raised within three miles of here and never went nowhar'.  It was powerful bad to be so far from home as I - she had thought of me a heap o' times- Mrs Adams seemed as if she had known better days - quite a fine looking woman.  Seven children to provide for and she sick often.  Liable to be prostrated at any time - lungs affected and have been for three years

Saturday May 7-
Wrote long letter to cousin L. Pond and mailed it - Sent her Painted cup and Anemone.  Sent Spring beauty - Dutchman's B - ((unclear)) Emil and Jenny in last letters - Isaac home before dinner - Harriet Smith here all P.M. made ((unclear)) book.  I looked through telescope off five miles on prairie saw cattle,houses, sheep about the houses - people in the doors, Everything in Nature looks now fresh & bright - as if no blight ever came - as if there were no time to die - But oh how soon these glorious things must wither & die!  Even now is the work begun - Sweet flowers fresh & fragrant - one week agone now bloom no more - They have lived their little hour and passed away - frail fading emblems of our fleeting life!  What a lesson ye teach.

Sabbath May 8 Brother ((J's?)) birth day - A new year begins with him - God's blessing be with him.
This Mr bird's last Sabbath with us for the present.  Leave for Buffalo to-morrow to be at meeting of Gen. Ass. His brother in law to supply the desk here at least part of the time.  Mr. Wood some.  Sabbath School interesting - Some new members.  New Library present - question books, class books &c - Isaac there till after eleven last eve numbering books and getting the Library in order.  Read "Cheever's Voices of Nature" with Isaac.
I fear something is wrong in my heart to day - I cannot forget the week as I like to do, and and think and dream alone of God & Heaven.  O how sweet to keep a sabbath holy unto God even to the end.
(Marginal note:) Mrs. Burgess brought me full bloom rose - first I have had

Monday May 9
A rose in full beauty on the bush by the door this morn -  Honeysuckle rich in odor as usual with the humming birds flitting around it . Mr. Rowley here to dinner and for the night.  Isaac home all the evening - a luxury for me -
Tuesday May 10 Mail from Mt. Hawkins early this morn.  Letter from mother & Anna and from Augusta.  Elias married and established - Maria pleaded very much, as I expected "Energetic, sensible little body" Anna call her.

Wednesday May 11
Gold came out of my tooth and troubled me - Isaac put in wax.  He left about four o'clock for Little Muddy - stops at Mt. Hawkins to night  Miss Farrar of N.J. arrived at Mr. Woods to take a place in the Pinckneyville school.  She was in Miss Pain's school & Miss Reynolds this P.M.
Gathered a boquet of honeysuckle clover, blackberry (low) & fringe tree blossoms and grass with star of Bethlehem - after supper - two or three roses out fully - so beautiful - so sweet - The "queen of flowers".  The sweet scented woodbine begins to lose its flowers - some drop every day - They turn yellow as they grow old making the vine look ((firm?)) fr. the variety of shades

Thursday May 12-
Went int the store and bought ten yards of print ((146?)) for Mrs. Adams and carried it over- She seemed full of gratitude would do anything in her power for me, if I needed.  Said their room was cold the stove wold not keep it warm these chilly damp nights.  I wish they had a better room.
Miss Farrar the new teacher here to dine - robust, healthy, good natured, in appearance - just about my stature - from Malone N.J. Miss Child, one of my sisters of '47 an intimate friend of hers.
New girl came to day - Ann Skipworth - here we have an opportunity to do some good - she is an ignorant girl and has the reputation of thieving occasionally and telling strange stories-

Friday May 13
Lirrie gone home this morn.  Seemed to feel a little sad at leaving.  I sung to her last night & this morn. at her solicitation.  Went out to walk - some fears of snakes in the fields but I was out so early this morn I do not  believe they were out of their nest.  I started up a pretty rabbit in the bushes.  It leaped a few rods and stopping turned to look at me watching me some time.
The pretty blue spiderwort & larkspur peeped out from the corners of the fences and gracefully bowed a good morning- just  wind enough this morn to make a soft murmuring among the leaves of the trees.  Our "park" is a lovely spot these days - Isaac came at night. brought me letter from home with lace in it-

Saturday - 14
At office in A.M. writing home & to Lucy Furber.  mail brought letter from Elias with the wedding card therein - He writes in good spirits and is happy - good news -
I went to ride with Mrs. Keyes in P.M. We got out of our way somewhat and found rough road but enjoyed the ride - woods full of flowers -
Sunday 15 - Rev. Mr. Wiley preached rather dull & slow.  Evidently uneducated and inexperienced.  Sabbath school interesting - some new members

Monday May 16

Wrote to our new sister - O how I dreaded to do it!  Finished letter home & to Sister Lucy & Isaac took them to M. Hawkins whither he went about noon - This is a fine day.  The gentlemen land seekers stopping here think this the finest place for country vill. in S. Illinois - one thinks he shall establish him here.

May 17 Tuesday -
