Twenty four to day. "To note it ((b?))e" but it does seem old - My 23d birth day was spent on the hills of my N.E. home - One year has wrought changes - great changes for me  My parents dwelling no more my home - far I am from childhood scenes - but happy - yea very happy with "one dear being."  My heart should

be full of praise this day for the unnumbered mercies of the year - O for strength and grace for the one to come.  Isaac home just at night -
Wednesday May 18 -
Isaac in office.  I with him all the A.M. Mr. Holt & ((Skinner?))
Thursday 19-
Rowley & Post here all day - Mrs. Root called.  Lent her ((Quichy & White?)) ((Slave?)) Important news from Samuel- The advent of a son -
20 Friday.  Isaac gone to big Muddy - Sewed & read - Slept a while after dinner - called at Mrs. Keyes after supper.
Saturday 21- Isaac very busy in office - Crosby & Rowley here at night - Mrs Adams & Julia called - She said she was cold in their cabin these damp chilly days - wish she had a better

Sabbath May 22
Did not go to church. My Isaac read the sermon as Mr. Sprague's request - Miss Reynolds heard my class all there but Josephine.
Monday - May 23
Isaac sent books to St. Louis to go to G.P. Putnam sent to him by mistake.  Then he started for Vandalia to be gone all the week.  I mended coat.   ((crossout unclear)) went to Mrs. Keyes and did a little washing.  In evening wrote to Albina.
Tuesday 24
Ironed and put up the mail - Letter came from Lirrie Hatch - both are well - she is teaching drawing & embroidery.  Mended pants and read newspapers.  2nd ((Dem?)) came fr. home.  It is good to look upon familiar names -

Wednesday 25
The sweet briar in full blossom to day.  the dear little meek things look like stars sprinkled over the green foliage of the bush.  Lettuce & pepper grass & asparagi one nearly overboard  Peas in full blossom.  Early ones have had long peas on them for several days.  The fringe tree truly is a splendid affair - growing more so daily
I mended and ironed in A.M. Mrs. Keyes & I went to ride in P.M. Tried to find strawberries, but they did not like to be found.  We nearly covered the bottom of our pail!  Called on  Mrs ((unclear)) blind she is and disabled by rheumatism one hand perfectly still the other nearly so - I do feel sorry for her she must sit and do nothing & see nothing as long as she lives - I love to listen to her converse
marginal note: first meal of fresh fish to day-

Thursday 26 May
Gone most of the A.M. with Mrs. Keyes on the Prairie for Strawberries - had enough for a delicious short cake for our suppers & some more. It was cool and we had a fine ride. I lay down and slept till dinner bell roused me.
Read "Now & then" by Warren - very interesting. Had currant pie for supper - most excellent and fresh fish at breakfast too bad altogether that Isaac is gone - and has not his share of our good things. I wanted to steal some and save for him saw wild roses on the prairie for the fist time this season. dear little modest things.

Friday 27 May
Lovely morn. been out to see the chickens- great many of them so many or they ran about so fast I could not count them.
People here think much of having chickens with green peas & corn.
Isaac home just at night.
Letter from Mother M. Good news from Bangor. Lucy doing finely, all joyful & thankful.
Saturday 28.

  Letter from Dunbarton Mother George & Jenny all write. Ge not very well - going to the seashore for a few weeks.

I at office short time in morning - mended parts where the rascally mouse mutilated them

 Sun almost scorching to day

Every thing dry - P for rain to invigorate & refresh all nature
[left-hand side] Miss Smith called

Sabbath May 29
Isaac read two sermons. Rather a warm day. fine shower at night . I did not go to meeting. Read Pastor's Sketches.
Monday May 30
Mailed letters Home, to Mother M. and to Lucy Brigham. Sent them to Mt. Hawkins - by Skinner. Drew a picture down to the office.
Tuesday - cut out shirt. Called on Mrs. Keyes and we together went to Mrs. Roots a few moments - looked at her flowers - visited the sport, prettily  and touchingly decorated with running roses turning honeysuckle Willow & Cypress where her husband lies.

wi' her needle and her sheers.
God's ould class look ancient as weel's the new;
___
"If one for whom Satan hath struggled as he hath for me, Should ever much that blissful shore!  I hope This heart will glow with gratitude & love!
___
